Ask HN: Google Maps alternative for planning and exploring?
text:
Google Maps is really good at taking me from point A to point B. But when I want to explore the map or plan a trip, I find it very clumsy and awkward to use.

I will preface this by saying that I have a really poor sense of direction, and that might be the cause of my frustration. Regardless, here are 2 examples:

Example 1: I want to know where city A is relative to a place I'm familiar with (city B or my house). I search for city A. The map zooms in on city A, which is fine. I then zoom out, trying to get a sense of where it is. But if it's in another country or far away from me, I'd have to zoom way out to even hit a place I know. So I try to search for a 2nd place that I know, hoping it'd show both places in one view. But instead it does a crazy pan to city B, completely disorienting me.

Example 2: I want to visit 2 places in one trip (think FedEx and UPS). I don't know their locations, but would like to make the shortest trip. I search for FedEx, and get maybe 5 results that are roughly the same distance from me. Then, I search for UPS, hoping to find one that's close to one of the 5 FedEx locations. But as soon as I hit search, all previous results go away and I'm back at square one.

To be honest I'm not sure exactly what I'm looking for. Is there a map UI that's significantly different from Google Maps that's worth trying?

Ask HN: Where to Find Asynchronous Work?
text:
Question:

Does anyone have recommendations on successfully earning money asynchronously? Are there alternative to being self-employed that may often be overlooked?

Background/Context: (not important for the average person)

My wife is going back to work and I want to continue home-schooling our young child. Due to our financial circumstances, I also need to earn money. I can plan short periods of time during the day to meet and collaborate with others but don't want to fall-back on using television as a babysitter more than necessary. I will not be able to baby-sit Slack or be available 30-40 hours/week for spontaneous video calls.

I have been working for various corporations for around a decade. Previously, I was a freelance developer (full-stack) for ~5 years. My current plan is to switch back to freelance development and independent consulting but the transition takes time; finding clients, building a fresh portfolio, etc. Additionally, I have small ideas in my personal backlog that I want to pursue.

We could wait until I've successfully made the transition but she got an offer that I believe will make her happy and would be difficult to beat. I believe I am personally dealing with burn-out and have been struggling for months with my full-time role. We are not in a financial situation to just take 6+ months off to recover and my mental health related to this position is not improving.

Thanks!
